texts.definition: Areas of game worlds that are not easily noticed.
markups: <style="Definition">Areas of game worlds that are not easily noticed.</style>

While most gameplay areas created for games are made so players naturally will visit them, some are <style="CurrentLink">Secret Areas</style> that players may need to explicitly search for in order to find. If players know these exist it gives them reason to explore the game worlds more throughly than otherwise, and even if they do not know about them finding one can provide surprises for them.

One of the first documented easter eggs in a game was a <style="CurrentLink">Secret Area</style>, a room in the game <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Adventure">Adventure</link></style> that revealed the name of its creator Warren Robinett.

Many <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:FPS%20Games">First-Person Shooters</link></style> like the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Doom%20series">Doom</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Quake%20series">Quake series</link></style> contain <style="CurrentLink">Secret Areas</style> with extra resources. The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Half-Life%20series">Half-Life series</link></style> include these as well, sometimes as caches for resistance fighters, as does the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Portal%20series">Portal series</link></style> with the dens of the ''rat man''.

There are two main ways of creating <style="CurrentLink">Secret Areas</style> in games. One is making areas difficult to notice due to the presence of <style="Link"><link="obstacles">Obstacles</link></style> and the other is to have areas completely hidden until unknown <style="Link"><link="conditional-passageways">Conditional Passageways</link></style> are activated. In both cases <style="Link"><link="clues">Clues</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="vision-modes">Vision Modes</link></style> can be used to make it easier to notice the <style="CurrentLink">Secret Areas</style> or at least hinting that something is unusual.

While <style="Link"><link="game-world-exploration">Game World Exploration</link></style> goals and <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style> may require players to find <style="CurrentLink">Secret Areas</style>, it is also quite common to provide them in order to offer players <style="Link"><link="optional-goals">Optional Goals</link></style> where they can earn <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> as  <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Secret Areas</style> are ways to hide parts of <style="Link"><link="game-boards">Game Boards</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style> to players, and may be intentional <style="Link"><link="easter-eggs">Easter Eggs</link></style>. Finding them may provide <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Surprises">Surprises</link></style> for players while if they know or suspect that the exist they may instead give rise to <style="Link"><link="game-world-exploration">Game World Exploration</link></style> activities. <style="CurrentLink">Secret Areas</style> can often function as <style="Link"><link="hiding-places">Hiding Places</link></style> since the <style="CurrentLink">Secret Areas</style> may be unknown both to other players and to <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> in a game.

Knowing about <style="CurrentLink">Secret Areas</style> are examples of <style="Link"><link="strategic-locations">Strategic Locations</link></style>, and these may even more likely be conveyed to others players as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Trans-Game%20Information">Trans-Game Information</link></style>. This is especially true when they are <style="Link"><link="hiding-places">Hiding Places</link></style> and these are not common.
